title: 113_hr512
content: The Act is named the "Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Act" and establishes a fellowship program for students from American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, and the United States Virgin Islands. The "Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Program" encourages civic engagement among students from American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, and the US Virgin Islands. It offers local and Federal Government fellowships to qualified students from these territories. The fellowships include opportunities with local government agencies or Federal Executive agencies. The "Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Program" promotes civic engagement among students from American Samoa, the Northern Mariana Islands, Guam, and the US Virgin Islands. Qualified students must be U.S. citizens, domiciled in these territories, and enrolled in a higher education program. The fellowship term is either an academic semester or summer, as determined by the Secretary. Fellowship awards are provided under the program. The fellowship award under the "Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Program" includes a stipend or academic credit, with a possible travel stipend of up to $1,500. The stipend amounts are $6,000 for an academic semester fellowship and $4,000 for a summer fellowship. For fiscal years after 2013, the stipend amounts are adjusted annually. The fellowship award under the "Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Program" includes a stipend or academic credit, with a possible travel stipend of up to $1,500. The stipend amounts are adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index and one percent of the previous year's amount. The Secretary will develop and administer an application and selection process for awarding the fellowship. Priority will be given in awarding the fellowship. The Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Program gives priority to students who have completed a fellowship before. Each student can receive one local government fellowship and one Federal Government fellowship. The Secretary must report to Congress on the program's fund usage and participation barriers within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Consumer Price Index is defined as the CPI for All Urban Consumers by the Department of Labor. The program refers to the Dr. Rita Hocog Inos Territorial Fellowship Program, and the Secretary is the Secretary of the Interior. Funding for the fellowship program can be sourced from appropriations for technical assistance to territories under the Department of the Interior for fiscal year 2013 onwards. No other funds can be used for this purpose.
